Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Today is the annual Sly Wizard Tournament
featuring competitors from the wizarding world’s
three greatest schools, and you’ve been entrusted
with an enormous responsibility. You are to administer the tournament. First, you and you alone will determine
how many events there will be and their scoring system. Then the three wizards will
enter your maze and compete in your chosen
events in utmost secrecy; only you and they will see what happens. The competition begins and... Wow, that was one for the record books. The winner was... wait, you have no idea. The last thing you remember was
a dark wizard showing up and casting a forgetting curse. The competitors seem even more confused—
each is convinced they won. This is bad. There can be no do-overs, and the last failure to declare a winner
set off the first Great Wizarding War. You’ve got to figure this out— and fast. But for the life of you,
you can’t remember a thing. You know you had to follow a few rules: there had to be three or more events,
each with a single winner and loser. Every event used the same scoring system, where first place received more points
than second, and second more than third. All points were positive integers. Maybe there’s a record somewhere...
oh, of course, your scorecard. Well, that leaves something to be desired. All that you wrote down was
that in Calchemy, Newt-niz won,
Leib-ton took second, and that was the only time
Magnificent Marigold’s Magical Macademy got third all day. Oh, and some final scores: one school got 22 points,
and both of the others got 9. Why are you so bad at taking notes?! No time for self-recrimination. The wizarding world is waiting. Who won the tournament? Pause here to figure it out yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 At first, it may seem like there are
an overwhelming number of possible scoring systems, so let's see if we can narrow our options. We can start by looking for clues
in the total scores. Every event was scored the same way, so the sum of all points
in the entire tournament must be a multiple of one event’s total. In other words, if there were three events
that scored 3, 2, 1, which adds up to 6,
the total points for the day would be 18, which is three events times 6 points. Our total is 40. So we can make a table of possibilities:
one event totaling 40 points, two totaling 20, four totaling 10,
and so on. We know there were at least three events,
which eliminates these options, and we can also get rid of events
with fewer than 6 points, because the smallest possible total
is 3 plus 2 plus 1. That leaves two prospects. Let’s try to narrow those further
by breaking down the possible points earned in each event: if first place received 7 points, the teams that had totals of 9
couldn’t have won an event because their total score
would be 10 or more. That means the team with 22
would have to have won all four. But then their total would be 28,
so we can eliminate that option. And with four events, these numbers
can't be made to add up to 22. Finally, if first place got 5 points, the highest possible score 
with four events would be 20, getting rid of these two as well. In fact, five events scoring 4 each
could only reach 20 as well. That leaves us with just one possibility: five events each scored 5, 2, 1. There’s exactly one way to make
those scores add up to 22: the winner finished first
four times and second once. The scores of 9 mean one team won once
and lost four times, and the other lost once
and took second four times. That must be Marigold’s Macademy, whose only third place finish
was Calchemy based on your note. And Leib-ton’s second place finish
in Calchemy means they scored 22 and won the Sly Wizard Tournament. You have just enough evidence to prove it,
keep your job, and avert war. Phew!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The sum of all points in the tournament must be ____.
Options: A. Less than 40, B. Greater than 20, C. A multiple of 6, D. A multiple of one event's total
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the minimum number of events that must be held in the Sly Wizard Tournament? Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4 Correct Option: C
Question 2: What information can be inferred from the fact that one school scored 22 points and the other two schools scored 9 points each? Options: A. The scoring system was based on a single event., B. The scoring system was based on multiple events with the same points allocation., C. The tournament had only two events., D. The tournament had only one winner. Correct Option: B
Question 3: If the total points for the day were 40, what can be concluded about the possible scoring systems for each event? Options: A. The sum of points for each event must be 40., B. The sum of points for each event must be a multiple of 40., C. The sum of points for each event must be a factor of 40., D. The sum of points for each event must be a prime number. Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why can the option of an event totaling 40 points be eliminated? Options: A. Because there were at least three events., B. Because the smallest possible total is 3 + 2 + 1., C. Because the teams that scored 9 points couldn't have won an event., D. Because the team with 22 points would have to have won all four events. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What would happen if the team with 22 points won all four events, assuming the first-place score is 7 points? Options: A. Their total score would be 22., B. Their total score would be 28., C. Their total score would be 20., D. Their total score would be 10. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the only possible scoring system left after eliminating the other options? Options: A. 4 events with 4 points each, B. 5 events with 4 points each, C. 5 events with 5, 2, 1 points each, D. 4 events with 5, 2, 1 points each Correct Option: C
Question 7: How can the scores of 9 points be achieved in the tournament, assuming the scoring system is 5 events with 5, 2, 1 points each? Options: A. One team won once and lost four times, and the other lost once and took second four times., B. One team won four times and lost once, and the other lost four times and took second once., C. One team won three times and lost twice, and the other lost three times and took second twice., D. One team won twice and lost three times, and the other lost twice and took second three times. Correct Option: A
Question 8: Which team won the Sly Wizard Tournament, based on the evidence provided? Options: A. Magnificent Marigold's Magical Macademy, B. Leib-ton's school, C. Newt-niz's school, D. Calchemy's school Correct Option: B
Question 9: What would have happened if the winner of the tournament couldn't be determined? Options: A. The tournament would be replayed., B. The winner would be chosen randomly., C. The tournament would be cancelled., D. The first Great Wizarding War would be set off. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What was the key piece of information that helped determine the winner of the tournament? Options: A. The total points scored by each team., B. The scoring system used for each event., C. The fact that Leib-ton took second place in Calchemy., D. The fact that Magnificent Marigold's Magical Macademy got third place only once. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This is because both questions deal with the relationship between the total points for the day and the possible scoring systems for each event. The ground truth MCQ asks about the sum of all points in the tournament, while Question 3 asks about what can be concluded about the possible scoring systems given the total points for the day. 

The correct options for both questions also convey the same idea: the sum of points for each event must be a factor or multiple of the total points for the day. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Today is the annual Sly Wizard Tournament
featuring competitors from the wizarding world’s
three greatest schools, and you’ve been entrusted
with an enormous responsibility. You are to administer the tournament. First, you and you alone will determine
how many events there will be and their scoring system. Then the three wizards will
enter your maze and compete in your chosen
events in utmost secrecy; only you and they will see what happens. The competition begins and... Wow, that was one for the record books. The winner was... wait, you have no idea. The last thing you remember was
a dark wizard showing up and casting a forgetting curse. The competitors seem even more confused—
each is convinced they won. This is bad. There can be no do-overs, and the last failure to declare a winner
set off the first Great Wizarding War. You’ve got to figure this out— and fast. But for the life of you,
you can’t remember a thing. You know you had to follow a few rules: there had to be three or more events,
each with a single winner and loser. Every event used the same scoring system, where first place received more points
than second, and second more than third. All points were positive integers. Maybe there’s a record somewhere...
oh, of course, your scorecard. Well, that leaves something to be desired. All that you wrote down was
that in Calchemy, Newt-niz won,
Leib-ton took second, and that was the only time
Magnificent Marigold’s Magical Macademy got third all day. Oh, and some final scores: one school got 22 points,
and both of the others got 9. Why are you so bad at taking notes?! No time for self-recrimination. The wizarding world is waiting. Who won the tournament? Pause here to figure it out yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 At first, it may seem like there are
an overwhelming number of possible scoring systems, so let's see if we can narrow our options. We can start by looking for clues
in the total scores. Every event was scored the same way, so the sum of all points
in the entire tournament must be a multiple of one event’s total. In other words, if there were three events
that scored 3, 2, 1, which adds up to 6,
the total points for the day would be 18, which is three events times 6 points. Our total is 40. So we can make a table of possibilities:
one event totaling 40 points, two totaling 20, four totaling 10,
and so on. We know there were at least three events,
which eliminates these options, and we can also get rid of events
with fewer than 6 points, because the smallest possible total
is 3 plus 2 plus 1. That leaves two prospects. Let’s try to narrow those further
by breaking down the possible points earned in each event: if first place received 7 points, the teams that had totals of 9
couldn’t have won an event because their total score
would be 10 or more. That means the team with 22
would have to have won all four. But then their total would be 28,
so we can eliminate that option. And with four events, these numbers
can't be made to add up to 22. Finally, if first place got 5 points, the highest possible score 
with four events would be 20, getting rid of these two as well. In fact, five events scoring 4 each
could only reach 20 as well. That leaves us with just one possibility: five events each scored 5, 2, 1. There’s exactly one way to make
those scores add up to 22: the winner finished first
four times and second once. The scores of 9 mean one team won once
and lost four times, and the other lost once
and took second four times. That must be Marigold’s Macademy, whose only third place finish
was Calchemy based on your note. And Leib-ton’s second place finish
in Calchemy means they scored 22 and won the Sly Wizard Tournament. You have just enough evidence to prove it,
keep your job, and avert war. Phew!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is a scoring requirement of the wizard tournament?
Options: A. 1st place earns one more point than 2nd place., B. 2nd place earns more points than 3rd place., C. 1st place earns 3 more points than 2nd place., D. 2nd place earns twice as many points as 3rd place.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the minimum number of events that must be held in the Sly Wizard Tournament? Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4 Correct Option: C
Question 2: What information can be inferred from the fact that one school scored 22 points and the other two schools scored 9 points each? Options: A. The scoring system was based on a single event., B. The scoring system was based on multiple events with the same points allocation., C. The tournament had only two events., D. The tournament had only one winner. Correct Option: B
Question 3: If the total points for the day were 40, what can be concluded about the possible scoring systems for each event? Options: A. The sum of points for each event must be 40., B. The sum of points for each event must be a multiple of 40., C. The sum of points for each event must be a factor of 40., D. The sum of points for each event must be a prime number. Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why can the option of an event totaling 40 points be eliminated? Options: A. Because there were at least three events., B. Because the smallest possible total is 3 + 2 + 1., C. Because the teams that scored 9 points couldn't have won an event., D. Because the team with 22 points would have to have won all four events. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What would happen if the team with 22 points won all four events, assuming the first-place score is 7 points? Options: A. Their total score would be 22., B. Their total score would be 28., C. Their total score would be 20., D. Their total score would be 10. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the only possible scoring system left after eliminating the other options? Options: A. 4 events with 4 points each, B. 5 events with 4 points each, C. 5 events with 5, 2, 1 points each, D. 4 events with 5, 2, 1 points each Correct Option: C
Question 7: How can the scores of 9 points be achieved in the tournament, assuming the scoring system is 5 events with 5, 2, 1 points each? Options: A. One team won once and lost four times, and the other lost once and took second four times., B. One team won four times and lost once, and the other lost four times and took second once., C. One team won three times and lost twice, and the other lost three times and took second twice., D. One team won twice and lost three times, and the other lost twice and took second three times. Correct Option: A
Question 8: Which team won the Sly Wizard Tournament, based on the evidence provided? Options: A. Magnificent Marigold's Magical Macademy, B. Leib-ton's school, C. Newt-niz's school, D. Calchemy's school Correct Option: B
Question 9: What would have happened if the winner of the tournament couldn't be determined? Options: A. The tournament would be replayed., B. The winner would be chosen randomly., C. The tournament would be cancelled., D. The first Great Wizarding War would be set off. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What was the key piece of information that helped determine the winner of the tournament? Options: A. The total points scored by each team., B. The scoring system used for each event., C. The fact that Leib-ton took second place in Calchemy., D. The fact that Magnificent Marigold's Magical Macademy got third place only once. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 3 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

However, since Question 3 does not directly address the scoring requirement, I re-examined the generated MCQs and found that none of them directly match the ground truth MCQ. But if I had to choose one, I would say that Question 6 is the closest, as it mentions a scoring system with points allocated to 1st, 2nd, and 3rd places.

But, if I were to choose a question that implies the scoring requirement stated in the ground truth MCQ, I would say Question 2 is the closest. It implies that the scoring system is based on multiple events with the same points allocation, which indirectly relates to the scoring requirement stated in the ground truth MCQ.

Since none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ, I will provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ based on implication:

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Today is the annual Sly Wizard Tournament
featuring competitors from the wizarding world’s
three greatest schools, and you’ve been entrusted
with an enormous responsibility. You are to administer the tournament. First, you and you alone will determine
how many events there will be and their scoring system. Then the three wizards will
enter your maze and compete in your chosen
events in utmost secrecy; only you and they will see what happens. The competition begins and... Wow, that was one for the record books. The winner was... wait, you have no idea. The last thing you remember was
a dark wizard showing up and casting a forgetting curse. The competitors seem even more confused—
each is convinced they won. This is bad. There can be no do-overs, and the last failure to declare a winner
set off the first Great Wizarding War. You’ve got to figure this out— and fast. But for the life of you,
you can’t remember a thing. You know you had to follow a few rules: there had to be three or more events,
each with a single winner and loser. Every event used the same scoring system, where first place received more points
than second, and second more than third. All points were positive integers. Maybe there’s a record somewhere...
oh, of course, your scorecard. Well, that leaves something to be desired. All that you wrote down was
that in Calchemy, Newt-niz won,
Leib-ton took second, and that was the only time
Magnificent Marigold’s Magical Macademy got third all day. Oh, and some final scores: one school got 22 points,
and both of the others got 9. Why are you so bad at taking notes?! No time for self-recrimination. The wizarding world is waiting. Who won the tournament? Pause here to figure it out yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 At first, it may seem like there are
an overwhelming number of possible scoring systems, so let's see if we can narrow our options. We can start by looking for clues
in the total scores. Every event was scored the same way, so the sum of all points
in the entire tournament must be a multiple of one event’s total. In other words, if there were three events
that scored 3, 2, 1, which adds up to 6,
the total points for the day would be 18, which is three events times 6 points. Our total is 40. So we can make a table of possibilities:
one event totaling 40 points, two totaling 20, four totaling 10,
and so on. We know there were at least three events,
which eliminates these options, and we can also get rid of events
with fewer than 6 points, because the smallest possible total
is 3 plus 2 plus 1. That leaves two prospects. Let’s try to narrow those further
by breaking down the possible points earned in each event: if first place received 7 points, the teams that had totals of 9
couldn’t have won an event because their total score
would be 10 or more. That means the team with 22
would have to have won all four. But then their total would be 28,
so we can eliminate that option. And with four events, these numbers
can't be made to add up to 22. Finally, if first place got 5 points, the highest possible score 
with four events would be 20, getting rid of these two as well. In fact, five events scoring 4 each
could only reach 20 as well. That leaves us with just one possibility: five events each scored 5, 2, 1. There’s exactly one way to make
those scores add up to 22: the winner finished first
four times and second once. The scores of 9 mean one team won once
and lost four times, and the other lost once
and took second four times. That must be Marigold’s Macademy, whose only third place finish
was Calchemy based on your note. And Leib-ton’s second place finish
in Calchemy means they scored 22 and won the Sly Wizard Tournament. You have just enough evidence to prove it,
keep your job, and avert war. Phew!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: After sorting through different scenarios, you determined that the wizard tournament had ___ events.
Options: A. 3, B. 4, C. 5, D. 6
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the minimum number of events that must be held in the Sly Wizard Tournament? Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4 Correct Option: C
Question 2: What information can be inferred from the fact that one school scored 22 points and the other two schools scored 9 points each? Options: A. The scoring system was based on a single event., B. The scoring system was based on multiple events with the same points allocation., C. The tournament had only two events., D. The tournament had only one winner. Correct Option: B
Question 3: If the total points for the day were 40, what can be concluded about the possible scoring systems for each event? Options: A. The sum of points for each event must be 40., B. The sum of points for each event must be a multiple of 40., C. The sum of points for each event must be a factor of 40., D. The sum of points for each event must be a prime number. Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why can the option of an event totaling 40 points be eliminated? Options: A. Because there were at least three events., B. Because the smallest possible total is 3 + 2 + 1., C. Because the teams that scored 9 points couldn't have won an event., D. Because the team with 22 points would have to have won all four events. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What would happen if the team with 22 points won all four events, assuming the first-place score is 7 points? Options: A. Their total score would be 22., B. Their total score would be 28., C. Their total score would be 20., D. Their total score would be 10. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the only possible scoring system left after eliminating the other options? Options: A. 4 events with 4 points each, B. 5 events with 4 points each, C. 5 events with 5, 2, 1 points each, D. 4 events with 5, 2, 1 points each Correct Option: C
Question 7: How can the scores of 9 points be achieved in the tournament, assuming the scoring system is 5 events with 5, 2, 1 points each? Options: A. One team won once and lost four times, and the other lost once and took second four times., B. One team won four times and lost once, and the other lost four times and took second once., C. One team won three times and lost twice, and the other lost three times and took second twice., D. One team won twice and lost three times, and the other lost twice and took second three times. Correct Option: A
Question 8: Which team won the Sly Wizard Tournament, based on the evidence provided? Options: A. Magnificent Marigold's Magical Macademy, B. Leib-ton's school, C. Newt-niz's school, D. Calchemy's school Correct Option: B
Question 9: What would have happened if the winner of the tournament couldn't be determined? Options: A. The tournament would be replayed., B. The winner would be chosen randomly., C. The tournament would be cancelled., D. The first Great Wizarding War would be set off. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What was the key piece of information that helped determine the winner of the tournament? Options: A. The total points scored by each team., B. The scoring system used for each event., C. The fact that Leib-ton took second place in Calchemy., D. The fact that Magnificent Marigold's Magical Macademy got third place only once. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ is Question 6: What is the only possible scoring system left after eliminating the other options? Options: A. 4 events with 4 points each, B. 5 events with 4 points each, C. 5 events with 5, 2, 1 points each, D. 4 events with 5, 2, 1 points each Correct Option: C.

However, this question does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the scoring system rather than the number of events. 

A more similar question would be one that directly asks about the number of events. Among the provided options, Question 1 is the closest match, but it asks about the minimum number of events rather than the actual number of events determined after sorting through scenarios.

If I had to choose the most similar question based on the provided options, I would choose Question 1 as the closest match, even though it does not perfectly align with the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

Today is the annual Sly Wizard Tournament
featuring competitors from the wizarding world’s
three greatest schools, and you’ve been entrusted

in Calchemy means they scored 22 and won the Sly Wizard Tournament. You have just enough evidence to prove it,
keep your job, and avert war. Phew!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place in each wizard tournament event was worth _____ points, respectively.
Options: A. 5/2/1, B. 3/2/1, C. 7/2/1, D. 5/3/2
Correct Option: A

Question 6: What is the only possible scoring system left after eliminating the other options? Options: A. 4 events with 4 points each, B. 5 events with 4 points each, C. 5 events with 5, 2, 1 points each, D. 4 events with 5, 2, 1 points each Correct Option: C
Question 7: How can the scores of 9 points be achieved in the tournament, assuming the scoring system is 5 events with 5, 2, 1 points each? Options: A. One team won once and lost four times, and the other lost once and took second four times., B. One team won four times and lost once, and the other lost four times and took second once., C. One team won three times and lost twice, and the other lost three times and took second twice., D. One team won twice and lost three times, and the other lost twice and took second three times. Correct Option: A
Question 8: Which team won the Sly Wizard Tournament, based on the evidence provided? Options: A. Magnificent Marigold's Magical Macademy, B. Leib-ton's school, C. Newt-niz's school, D. Calchemy's school Correct Option: B
Question 9: What would have happened if the winner of the tournament couldn't be determined? Options: A. The tournament would be replayed., B. The winner would be chosen randomly., C. The tournament would be cancelled., D. The first Great Wizarding War would be set off. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What was the key piece of information that helped determine the winner of the tournament? Options: A. The total points scored by each team., B. The scoring system used for each event., C. The fact that Leib-ton took second place in Calchemy., D. The fact that Magnificent Marigold's Magical Macademy got third place only once. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ is Question 6: What is the only possible scoring system left after eliminating the other options? 

Options: A. 4 events with 4 points each, B. 5 events with 4 points each, C. 5 events with 5, 2, 1 points each, D. 4 events with 5, 2, 1 points each 

Correct Option: C

This question directly addresses the scoring system used in the tournament, which is the main focus of the ground truth MCQ. Although the wording and options are not identical, the intent and content of the two questions are closely matched.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Today is the annual Sly Wizard Tournament
featuring competitors from the wizarding world’s
three greatest schools, and you’ve been entrusted
with an enormous responsibility. You are to administer the tournament. First, you and you alone will determine
how many events there will be and their scoring system. Then the three wizards will
enter your maze and compete in your chosen
events in utmost secrecy; only you and they will see what happens. The competition begins and... Wow, that was one for the record books. The winner was... wait, you have no idea. The last thing you remember was
a dark wizard showing up and casting a forgetting curse. The competitors seem even more confused—
each is convinced they won. This is bad. There can be no do-overs, and the last failure to declare a winner
set off the first Great Wizarding War. You’ve got to figure this out— and fast. But for the life of you,
you can’t remember a thing. You know you had to follow a few rules: there had to be three or more events,
each with a single winner and loser. Every event used the same scoring system, where first place received more points
than second, and second more than third. All points were positive integers. Maybe there’s a record somewhere...
oh, of course, your scorecard. Well, that leaves something to be desired. All that you wrote down was
that in Calchemy, Newt-niz won,
Leib-ton took second, and that was the only time
Magnificent Marigold’s Magical Macademy got third all day. Oh, and some final scores: one school got 22 points,
and both of the others got 9. Why are you so bad at taking notes?! No time for self-recrimination. The wizarding world is waiting. Who won the tournament? Pause here to figure it out yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 At first, it may seem like there are
an overwhelming number of possible scoring systems, so let's see if we can narrow our options. We can start by looking for clues
in the total scores. Every event was scored the same way, so the sum of all points
in the entire tournament must be a multiple of one event’s total. In other words, if there were three events
that scored 3, 2, 1, which adds up to 6,
the total points for the day would be 18, which is three events times 6 points. Our total is 40. So we can make a table of possibilities:
one event totaling 40 points, two totaling 20, four totaling 10,
and so on. We know there were at least three events,
which eliminates these options, and we can also get rid of events
with fewer than 6 points, because the smallest possible total
is 3 plus 2 plus 1. That leaves two prospects. Let’s try to narrow those further
by breaking down the possible points earned in each event: if first place received 7 points, the teams that had totals of 9
couldn’t have won an event because their total score
would be 10 or more. That means the team with 22
would have to have won all four. But then their total would be 28,
so we can eliminate that option. And with four events, these numbers
can't be made to add up to 22. Finally, if first place got 5 points, the highest possible score 
with four events would be 20, getting rid of these two as well. In fact, five events scoring 4 each
could only reach 20 as well. That leaves us with just one possibility: five events each scored 5, 2, 1. There’s exactly one way to make
those scores add up to 22: the winner finished first
four times and second once. The scores of 9 mean one team won once
and lost four times, and the other lost once
and took second four times. That must be Marigold’s Macademy, whose only third place finish
was Calchemy based on your note. And Leib-ton’s second place finish
in Calchemy means they scored 22 and won the Sly Wizard Tournament. You have just enough evidence to prove it,
keep your job, and avert war. Phew!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The tournament winner earned a total of how many points?
Options: A. 20, B. 22, C. 40, D. 10
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the minimum number of events that must be held in the Sly Wizard Tournament? Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4 Correct Option: C
Question 2: What information can be inferred from the fact that one school scored 22 points and the other two schools scored 9 points each? Options: A. The scoring system was based on a single event., B. The scoring system was based on multiple events with the same points allocation., C. The tournament had only two events., D. The tournament had only one winner. Correct Option: B
Question 3: If the total points for the day were 40, what can be concluded about the possible scoring systems for each event? Options: A. The sum of points for each event must be 40., B. The sum of points for each event must be a multiple of 40., C. The sum of points for each event must be a factor of 40., D. The sum of points for each event must be a prime number. Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why can the option of an event totaling 40 points be eliminated? Options: A. Because there were at least three events., B. Because the smallest possible total is 3 + 2 + 1., C. Because the teams that scored 9 points couldn't have won an event., D. Because the team with 22 points would have to have won all four events. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What would happen if the team with 22 points won all four events, assuming the first-place score is 7 points? Options: A. Their total score would be 22., B. Their total score would be 28., C. Their total score would be 20., D. Their total score would be 10. Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The following statement
is utterly ludicrous. It is also true. The world's most important
advanced technology is nearly all produced
in a single facility. What's more, that facility is located in one of the most geopolitically
fraught areas on Earth, an area in which many analysts believe
that war is inevitable within the decade. The future of artificial intelligence
hangs in the balance. The Taiwan Semiconductor
Manufacturing Company, or TSMC, makes all of the world's
most-advanced AI chips. This includes Nvidia's GPUs,
Google's TPUs, AMD's GPUs, the AI chips for Microsoft, Amazon, Tesla, Cerebrus, SambaNova and every other credible competitor. Modern artificial intelligence
simply would not be possible without these highly specialized chips. Little wonder, then, that Time magazine recently
described TSMC as, "The world's most important company
that you've probably never heard of." Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang
put it more colorfully, saying, “Basically,
there is air ... and TSMC.” (Laughter) TSMC's chip fabrication
facilities, or fabs, the buildings where chips
are physically built, is located on the western coast of Taiwan, a mere 110 miles from mainland China. In this map, Taiwan is shown in orange
and China is shown in green. Today, China and Taiwan
are nearer to the brink of war than they have been in decades. Many policymakers in Washington predict
that China will invade Taiwan within the next five years. A China-Taiwan conflict
would be devastating for many reasons. Aside from the heavy human toll, one underappreciated consequence is that it would paralyze
the global AI ecosystem. Put simply, the entire field
of artificial intelligence faces an astonishingly precarious
single point of failure in Taiwan. Amid all of the fervor around AI today, this fact is not widely
enough appreciated. If you are working on
or are interested in AI, you need to be paying attention. How did we get here
and what can we do about it? Let's start with a brief, whirlwind
overview of the chip industry. Semiconductors, or chips,
are the most complex object in the world that humanity knows how to mass-produce. Making semiconductors requires
the world's purest metals, the world's most expensive machinery, legions of highly specialized engineers and atom-level manufacturing precision. It is important to distinguish between two
different types of chip companies. First, fabless chip makers, which design but do not
manufacture their own chips. And second, foundries, which manufacture chips
designed by other companies. Almost every well-known chip
company today is fabless, from Nvidia to AMD to Qualcomm. These companies do not
produce their own chips. Instead, they design chips, and then they rely on foundries like TSMC to actually manufacture
those chips for them. There are only three companies
in the world today that are capable of manufacturing chips anywhere near the leading edge
of semiconductor technology: TSMC, Samsung and Intel. Of those three, only one can reliably produce
the world's most advanced AI chips, including chips like Nvidia's H100 GPUs. That one company is TSMC. As of this morning, TSMC's market capitalization
was 470 billion dollars, making it the 13th-largest
company in the world, larger than ExxonMobil, JPMorgan Chase or Walmart. How has TSMC become such a dominant force? The short answer is that powerful
economies of scale exist in the world of chip fabrication, leading inexorably
to winner-take-all dynamics. Making advanced semiconductors
requires tremendous upfront and ongoing capital expenditure. In 2021, TSMC announced
that it would invest 100 billion dollars over the next three years to continue expanding
its fabrication capabilities. No other company in the world
can justify that level of investment. TSMC can, because of the sheer volume
of chips that it produces, far more than any other
company in the world. A related dynamic that helps explain
TSMC's unassailable position is what has come to be known
as the TSMC Grand Alliance. TSMC has invested heavily over decades to develop deep partnerships
with dozens of companies across the semiconductor supply chain, from software providers like Cadence to equipment manufacturers like ASML to chip designers like Nvidia. In turn, these companies
have developed their own products in accordance with TSMC's road map, leading to powerful lock-in. In summary, a combination
of economies of scale, network effects, and unrivaled specialization
have made TSMC irreplaceable and have made the entire world deeply,
precariously dependent upon it. This brings us to the present,
delicate geopolitical moment. Last October, the Biden administration
took the dramatic step of banning the export of all high-end
AI chips to any entity in China. The rationale behind
these measures was clear. To leverage US control of the global semiconductor supply chain as a choke point to handicap
China's AI capabilities. The US government is currently formulating
expansions to this policy. At the same time, the US is taking steps
to reduce its reliance on chip fabrication facilities
located in East Asia. In late 2022, TSMC announced that it would
invest 40 billion dollars to build two new state-of-the-art fabs in the United States, in Arizona. The first of these two fabs is slated
to begin production in 2025. Bringing advanced
chip production to US soil will help mitigate the AI industry's
absolute dependence on Taiwan-based fabs. But the Arizona fabs
will not solve everything. Their production capacity will be modest, representing less than five percent
of TSMC's total global output. And the most advanced semiconductor
production capabilities and technologies will remain in Taiwan. So where might things go from here? Let's briefly consider
a few possibilities on this three-dimensional chessboard. Let's start with optimistic scenario. Taiwan's central role in the global
semiconductor industry is often referred to
as its “silicon shield.” The basic theory is this: because China depends so heavily on Taiwan
for the chips that it needs to keep its own economy running, China will stop short of invading Taiwan
and putting TSMC's production at risk. And because the rest of the world
is likewise so dependent on TSMC, the United States and other powers
will go to great lengths to protect the island
and defend its sovereignty. Under this theory, while China may continue
to build out its military and engage in cross-strait saber-rattling, it will stop short of kinetic
action against Taiwan. But the silicon shield is just a theory, not a guarantee. What would happen if China
were to move decisively to retake Taiwan? TSMC's fabs would almost certainly
be rendered inoperative. It is conceivable that the Taiwanese,
or even the US military, would preemptively destroy the fabs in order to prevent the CCP from taking control of this
valuable strategic resource. Even if the physical buildings
were to remain undamaged after a Chinese invasion, it is unrealistic that the CCP would be
able to continue operating the fabs to produce cutting-edge chips. Keeping leading edge fabs running requires ongoing and deep partnership with organizations across the global
semiconductor ecosystem, as well as a steady inflow of materials,
equipment and services. These would be denied
to an invading power. Let me say this one more time: if or when China invades Taiwan, TSMC's fabs will,
in all likelihood, go offline. This will mean that no more Nvidia H100s or any other cutting-edge AI chips will be able to be produced
anywhere in the world. What would this mean for the world of AI? After TSMC, the company
best positioned to step up and produce cutting-edge
AI chips is Samsung. Samsung is currently the only company
in the world, other than TSMC, that is capable of producing
three-nanometer chips, today's cutting-edge technology. But Samsung's production capabilities
are far inferior to TSMC's today. In a best-case scenario, it would take Samsung years to scale up to TSMC's current AI
chip yields and volumes. This brings us to America's
former chip champion, Intel. It was hardly a decade ago that Intel's chip-manufacturing
capabilities were the envy of the world. But in recent years,
Intel has fallen behind. The company struggled mightily
in its transition to both ten-nanometer and seven-nanometer node technologies, even resorting to outsourcing some
of its leading edge production to TSMC. Under CEO Pat Gelsinger, Intel aspires to regain
its chipmaking supremacy with an ambitious plan to leapfrog TSMC and begin producing
two-nanometer chips in 2024. Whether this ambitious plan will actually
prove achievable, however, remains to be seen. Before we despair too much, let us note a couple encouraging points. First, keep in mind that a considerable
stock of AI chips already exists in the world. And even in a worst-case scenario,
these chips would remain in use. Second, while the most advanced AI chips,
like Google’s TPUs or Nvidia’s H100s, can only be manufactured in Taiwan, there are many fabs around the world, from the US to Europe to Israel, that are capable of producing
lagging-edge logic chips at scale. Though they are far less powerful
than today's leading AI chips, these previous-generation chips
could be used in a pinch to support some AI computing workloads. Ultimately, though, it would be
devastating for humanity to lose its ability to produce the chips that power today's cutting-edge
artificial intelligence. Progress in AI would be
profoundly disrupted. Let us hope that diplomacy prevails. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) is crucial for AI technology because it:
Options: A. Provides consultation services to AI companies., B. Makes all of the world's most-advanced AI chips., C. Offers free software for AI development., D. Conducts AI research and development.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What company is described as "the world's most important company that you've probably never heard of" by Time magazine? Options: A. Nvidia, B. TSMC, C. Intel, D. Samsung Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary reason why a China-Taiwan conflict would be devastating for the global AI ecosystem? Options: A. The human toll would be too high, B. The global economy would suffer greatly, C. TSMC's chip fabrication facilities would be rendered inoperative, D. The conflict would disrupt global supply chains Correct Option: C
Question 3: What type of chip company designs but does not manufacture its own chips? Options: A. Foundry, B. Fabless chip maker, C. Semiconductor company, D. Integrated circuit manufacturer Correct Option: B
Question 4: Which of the following companies is capable of reliably producing the world's most advanced AI chips? Options: A. TSMC, Samsung, and Intel, B. Only TSMC, C. Only Samsung, D. Only Intel Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the main reason why TSMC has become a dominant force in the chip industry? Options: A. Its strategic location in Taiwan, B. Its ability to produce high-quality chips at a low cost, C. The powerful economies of scale in chip fabrication, D. Its strong partnerships with other companies Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the TSMC Grand Alliance, and how does it contribute to TSMC's success? Options: A. The TSMC Grand Alliance is a partnership between TSMC and the Taiwanese government, which provides TSMC with funding and resources., B. The TSMC Grand Alliance is a network of companies that work together to develop new chip technologies., C. The TSMC Grand Alliance is a group of companies that have developed their products in accordance with TSMC's road map, leading to powerful lock-in., D. The TSMC Grand Alliance is a marketing strategy used by TSMC to promote its products. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the "silicon shield" theory, and how does it relate to Taiwan's role in the global semiconductor industry? Options: A. The silicon shield theory states that Taiwan's central role in the global semiconductor industry protects it from invasion by China., B. The silicon shield theory states that Taiwan's semiconductor industry is vulnerable to disruption by China., C. The silicon shield theory states that the global semiconductor industry is dependent on Taiwan, but this dependence does not provide any protection against invasion., D. The silicon shield theory states that Taiwan's semiconductor industry is not important to the global economy. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What would happen to the global AI ecosystem if TSMC's chip fabrication facilities were rendered inoperative due to a China-Taiwan conflict? Options: A. The global AI ecosystem would be severely disrupted, but it would recover quickly., B. The global AI ecosystem would be mildly disrupted, but it would recover eventually., C. The global AI ecosystem would be devastated, and progress in AI would be profoundly disrupted., D. The global AI ecosystem would not be affected at all. Correct Option: C
Question 9: Which company is best positioned to step up and produce cutting-edge AI chips if TSMC's facilities are rendered inoperative? Options: A. Samsung, B. Intel, C. Nvidia, D. Google Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main challenge facing Intel as it tries to regain its chipmaking supremacy? Options: A. Intel's struggle to transition to new node technologies, B. Intel's lack of funding and resources, C. Intel's inability to compete with TSMC's economies of scale, D. Intel's failure to develop new chip technologies Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4: "Which of the following companies is capable of reliably producing the world's most advanced AI chips?"

This question has a similar intent and content to the ground truth MCQ, which asks why TSMC is crucial for AI technology. The correct option for Question 4, "Only TSMC", is similar to the correct option for the ground truth MCQ, "Makes all of the world's most-advanced AI chips." Both questions highlight TSMC's unique role in producing advanced AI chips.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:

is utterly ludicrous. It is also true. The world's most important

or even the US military, would preemptively destroy the fabs in order to prevent the CCP from taking control of this

equipment and services. These would be denied
to an invading power. Let me say this one more time: if or when China invades Taiwan, TSMC's fabs will,
in all likelihood, go offline. This will mean that no more Nvidia H100s or any other cutting-edge AI chips will be able to be produced
anywhere in the world. What would this mean for the world of AI? After TSMC, the company
best positioned to step up and produce cutting-edge
AI chips is Samsung. Samsung is currently the only company
in the world, other than TSMC, that is capable of producing
three-nanometer chips, today's cutting-edge technology. But Samsung's production capabilities
are far inferior to TSMC's today. In a best-case scenario, it would take Samsung years to scale up to TSMC's current AI
chip yields and volumes. This brings us to America's
former chip champion, Intel. It was hardly a decade ago that Intel's chip-manufacturing
capabilities were the envy of the world. But in recent years,
Intel has fallen behind. The company struggled mightily
in its transition to both ten-nanometer and seven-nanometer node technologies, even resorting to outsourcing some
of its leading edge production to TSMC. Under CEO Pat Gelsinger, Intel aspires to regain
its chipmaking supremacy with an ambitious plan to leapfrog TSMC and begin producing
two-nanometer chips in 2024. Whether this ambitious plan will actually
prove achievable, however, remains to be seen. Before we despair too much, let us note a couple encouraging points. First, keep in mind that a considerable
stock of AI chips already exists in the world. And even in a worst-case scenario,
these chips would remain in use. Second, while the most advanced AI chips,
like Google’s TPUs or Nvidia’s H100s, can only be manufactured in Taiwan, there are many fabs around the world, from the US to Europe to Israel, that are capable of producing
lagging-edge logic chips at scale. Though they are far less powerful
than today's leading AI chips, these previous-generation chips
could be used in a pinch to support some AI computing workloads. Ultimately, though, it would be
devastating for humanity to lose its ability to produce the chips that power today's cutting-edge
artificial intelligence. Progress in AI would be
profoundly disrupted. Let us hope that diplomacy prevails. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What would be one of the consequences of a conflict between China and Taiwan?
Options: A. Increase in global chip prices., B. Immediate technological advancements., C. Strengthening of global chip manufacturing diversity., D. Paralysis of the global AI ecosystem.
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What company is described as "the world's most important company that you've probably never heard of" by Time magazine? Options: A. Nvidia, B. TSMC, C. Intel, D. Samsung Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary reason why a China-Taiwan conflict would be devastating for the global AI ecosystem? Options: A. The human toll would be too high, B. The global economy would suffer greatly, C. TSMC's chip fabrication facilities would be rendered inoperative, D. The conflict would disrupt global supply chains Correct Option: C
Question 3: What type of chip company designs but does not manufacture its own chips? Options: A. Foundry, B. Fabless chip maker, C. Semiconductor company, D. Integrated circuit manufacturer Correct Option: B
Question 4: Which of the following companies is capable of reliably producing the world's most advanced AI chips? Options: A. TSMC, Samsung, and Intel, B. Only TSMC, C. Only Samsung, D. Only Intel Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the main reason why TSMC has become a dominant force in the chip industry? Options: A. Its strategic location in Taiwan, B. Its ability to produce high-quality chips at a low cost, C. The powerful economies of scale in chip fabrication, D. Its strong partnerships with other companies Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the TSMC Grand Alliance, and how does it contribute to TSMC's success? Options: A. The TSMC Grand Alliance is a partnership between TSMC and the Taiwanese government, which provides TSMC with funding and resources., B. The TSMC Grand Alliance is a network of companies that work together to develop new chip technologies., C. The TSMC Grand Alliance is a group of companies that have developed their products in accordance with TSMC's road map, leading to powerful lock-in., D. The TSMC Grand Alliance is a marketing strategy used by TSMC to promote its products. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the "silicon shield" theory, and how does it relate to Taiwan's role in the global semiconductor industry? Options: A. The silicon shield theory states that Taiwan's central role in the global semiconductor industry protects it from invasion by China., B. The silicon shield theory states that Taiwan's semiconductor industry is vulnerable to disruption by China., C. The silicon shield theory states that the global semiconductor industry is dependent on Taiwan, but this dependence does not provide any protection against invasion., D. The silicon shield theory states that Taiwan's semiconductor industry is not important to the global economy. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What would happen to the global AI ecosystem if TSMC's chip fabrication facilities were rendered inoperative due to a China-Taiwan conflict? Options: A. The global AI ecosystem would be severely disrupted, but it would recover quickly., B. The global AI ecosystem would be mildly disrupted, but it would recover eventually., C. The global AI ecosystem would be devastated, and progress in AI would be profoundly disrupted., D. The global AI ecosystem would not be affected at all. Correct Option: C
Question 9: Which company is best positioned to step up and produce cutting-edge AI chips if TSMC's facilities are rendered inoperative? Options: A. Samsung, B. Intel, C. Nvidia, D. Google Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main challenge facing Intel as it tries to regain its chipmaking supremacy? Options: A. Intel's struggle to transition to new node technologies, B. Intel's lack of funding and resources, C. Intel's inability to compete with TSMC's economies of scale, D. Intel's failure to develop new chip technologies Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the consequences of a conflict between China and Taiwan on the global AI ecosystem. The correct option, "The global AI ecosystem would be devastated, and progress in AI would be profoundly disrupted," is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, "Paralysis of the global AI ecosystem." 

While the wording is not identical, the meaning and intent of the two questions are very similar, making Question 8 the most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The following statement
is utterly ludicrous. It is also true. The world's most important
advanced technology is nearly all produced
in a single facility. What's more, that facility is located in one of the most geopolitically
fraught areas on Earth, an area in which many analysts believe
that war is inevitable within the decade. The future of artificial intelligence
hangs in the balance. The Taiwan Semiconductor
Manufacturing Company, or TSMC, makes all of the world's
most-advanced AI chips. This includes Nvidia's GPUs,
Google's TPUs, AMD's GPUs, the AI chips for Microsoft, Amazon, Tesla, Cerebrus, SambaNova and every other credible competitor. Modern artificial intelligence
simply would not be possible without these highly specialized chips. Little wonder, then, that Time magazine recently
described TSMC as, "The world's most important company
that you've probably never heard of." Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang
put it more colorfully, saying, “Basically,
there is air ... and TSMC.” (Laughter) TSMC's chip fabrication
facilities, or fabs, the buildings where chips
are physically built, is located on the western coast of Taiwan, a mere 110 miles from mainland China. In this map, Taiwan is shown in orange
and China is shown in green. Today, China and Taiwan
are nearer to the brink of war than they have been in decades. Many policymakers in Washington predict
that China will invade Taiwan within the next five years. A China-Taiwan conflict
would be devastating for many reasons. Aside from the heavy human toll, one underappreciated consequence is that it would paralyze
the global AI ecosystem. Put simply, the entire field
of artificial intelligence faces an astonishingly precarious
single point of failure in Taiwan. Amid all of the fervor around AI today, this fact is not widely
enough appreciated. If you are working on
or are interested in AI, you need to be paying attention. How did we get here
and what can we do about it? Let's start with a brief, whirlwind
overview of the chip industry. Semiconductors, or chips,
are the most complex object in the world that humanity knows how to mass-produce. Making semiconductors requires
the world's purest metals, the world's most expensive machinery, legions of highly specialized engineers and atom-level manufacturing precision. It is important to distinguish between two
different types of chip companies. First, fabless chip makers, which design but do not
manufacture their own chips. And second, foundries, which manufacture chips
designed by other companies. Almost every well-known chip
company today is fabless, from Nvidia to AMD to Qualcomm. These companies do not
produce their own chips. Instead, they design chips, and then they rely on foundries like TSMC to actually manufacture
those chips for them. There are only three companies
in the world today that are capable of manufacturing chips anywhere near the leading edge
of semiconductor technology: TSMC, Samsung and Intel. Of those three, only one can reliably produce
the world's most advanced AI chips, including chips like Nvidia's H100 GPUs. That one company is TSMC. As of this morning, TSMC's market capitalization
was 470 billion dollars, making it the 13th-largest
company in the world, larger than ExxonMobil, JPMorgan Chase or Walmart. How has TSMC become such a dominant force? The short answer is that powerful
economies of scale exist in the world of chip fabrication, leading inexorably
to winner-take-all dynamics. Making advanced semiconductors
requires tremendous upfront and ongoing capital expenditure. In 2021, TSMC announced
that it would invest 100 billion dollars over the next three years to continue expanding
its fabrication capabilities. No other company in the world
can justify that level of investment. TSMC can, because of the sheer volume
of chips that it produces, far more than any other
company in the world. A related dynamic that helps explain
TSMC's unassailable position is what has come to be known
as the TSMC Grand Alliance. TSMC has invested heavily over decades to develop deep partnerships
with dozens of companies across the semiconductor supply chain, from software providers like Cadence to equipment manufacturers like ASML to chip designers like Nvidia. In turn, these companies
have developed their own products in accordance with TSMC's road map, leading to powerful lock-in. In summary, a combination
of economies of scale, network effects, and unrivaled specialization
have made TSMC irreplaceable and have made the entire world deeply,
precariously dependent upon it. This brings us to the present,
delicate geopolitical moment. Last October, the Biden administration
took the dramatic step of banning the export of all high-end
AI chips to any entity in China. The rationale behind
these measures was clear. To leverage US control of the global semiconductor supply chain as a choke point to handicap
China's AI capabilities. The US government is currently formulating
expansions to this policy. At the same time, the US is taking steps
to reduce its reliance on chip fabrication facilities
located in East Asia. In late 2022, TSMC announced that it would
invest 40 billion dollars to build two new state-of-the-art fabs in the United States, in Arizona. The first of these two fabs is slated
to begin production in 2025. Bringing advanced
chip production to US soil will help mitigate the AI industry's
absolute dependence on Taiwan-based fabs. But the Arizona fabs
will not solve everything. Their production capacity will be modest, representing less than five percent
of TSMC's total global output. And the most advanced semiconductor
production capabilities and technologies will remain in Taiwan. So where might things go from here? Let's briefly consider
a few possibilities on this three-dimensional chessboard. Let's start with optimistic scenario. Taiwan's central role in the global
semiconductor industry is often referred to
as its “silicon shield.” The basic theory is this: because China depends so heavily on Taiwan
for the chips that it needs to keep its own economy running, China will stop short of invading Taiwan
and putting TSMC's production at risk. And because the rest of the world
is likewise so dependent on TSMC, the United States and other powers
will go to great lengths to protect the island
and defend its sovereignty. Under this theory, while China may continue
to build out its military and engage in cross-strait saber-rattling, it will stop short of kinetic
action against Taiwan. But the silicon shield is just a theory, not a guarantee. What would happen if China
were to move decisively to retake Taiwan? TSMC's fabs would almost certainly
be rendered inoperative. It is conceivable that the Taiwanese,
or even the US military, would preemptively destroy the fabs in order to prevent the CCP from taking control of this
valuable strategic resource. Even if the physical buildings
were to remain undamaged after a Chinese invasion, it is unrealistic that the CCP would be
able to continue operating the fabs to produce cutting-edge chips. Keeping leading edge fabs running requires ongoing and deep partnership with organizations across the global
semiconductor ecosystem, as well as a steady inflow of materials,
equipment and services. These would be denied
to an invading power. Let me say this one more time: if or when China invades Taiwan, TSMC's fabs will,
in all likelihood, go offline. This will mean that no more Nvidia H100s or any other cutting-edge AI chips will be able to be produced
anywhere in the world. What would this mean for the world of AI? After TSMC, the company
best positioned to step up and produce cutting-edge
AI chips is Samsung. Samsung is currently the only company
in the world, other than TSMC, that is capable of producing
three-nanometer chips, today's cutting-edge technology. But Samsung's production capabilities
are far inferior to TSMC's today. In a best-case scenario, it would take Samsung years to scale up to TSMC's current AI
chip yields and volumes. This brings us to America's
former chip champion, Intel. It was hardly a decade ago that Intel's chip-manufacturing
capabilities were the envy of the world. But in recent years,
Intel has fallen behind. The company struggled mightily
in its transition to both ten-nanometer and seven-nanometer node technologies, even resorting to outsourcing some
of its leading edge production to TSMC. Under CEO Pat Gelsinger, Intel aspires to regain
its chipmaking supremacy with an ambitious plan to leapfrog TSMC and begin producing
two-nanometer chips in 2024. Whether this ambitious plan will actually
prove achievable, however, remains to be seen. Before we despair too much, let us note a couple encouraging points. First, keep in mind that a considerable
stock of AI chips already exists in the world. And even in a worst-case scenario,
these chips would remain in use. Second, while the most advanced AI chips,
like Google’s TPUs or Nvidia’s H100s, can only be manufactured in Taiwan, there are many fabs around the world, from the US to Europe to Israel, that are capable of producing
lagging-edge logic chips at scale. Though they are far less powerful
than today's leading AI chips, these previous-generation chips
could be used in a pinch to support some AI computing workloads. Ultimately, though, it would be
devastating for humanity to lose its ability to produce the chips that power today's cutting-edge
artificial intelligence. Progress in AI would be
profoundly disrupted. Let us hope that diplomacy prevails. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which companies rely on foundries like TSMC to manufacture their chips?
Options: A. Only small and medium-sized enterprises., B. Only companies outside of the technology sector., C. Well-known chip companies like Nvidia, AMD, and Qualcomm., D. Companies that are focused exclusively on hardware.
Correct Option: C

The global economy would suffer greatly, C. TSMC's chip fabrication facilities would be rendered inoperative, D. The conflict would disrupt global supply chains Correct Option: C

The silicon shield theory states that Taiwan's semiconductor industry is vulnerable to disruption by China., C. The silicon shield theory states that the global semiconductor industry is dependent on Taiwan, but this dependence does not provide any protection against invasion., D. The silicon shield theory states that Taiwan's semiconductor industry is not important to the global economy. Correct Option: A

The global AI ecosystem would be severely disrupted, but it would recover quickly., B. The global AI ecosystem would be mildly disrupted, but it would recover eventually., C. The global AI ecosystem would be devastated, and progress in AI would be profoundly disrupted., D. The global AI ecosystem would not be affected at all. Correct Option: C

Intel's lack of funding and resources, C. Intel's inability to compete with TSMC's economies of scale, D. Intel's failure to develop new chip technologies Correct Option: A

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 3: What type of chip company designs but does not manufacture its own chips? Options: A. Foundry, B. Fabless chip maker, C. Semiconductor company, D. Integrated circuit manufacturer Correct Option: B**

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ asks about companies that rely on foundries like TSMC to manufacture their chips, and the correct option is "Well-known chip companies like Nvidia, AMD, and Qualcomm." The generated MCQ asks about the type of chip company that designs but does not manufacture its own chips, and the correct option is "Fabless chip maker." The two questions are related, as fabless chip makers are companies that design chips but do not manufacture them, and instead rely on foundries like TSMC.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **3**

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is referred to as Taiwan's "silicon shield"?
Options: A. The theory that China will avoid invading Taiwan due to its dependence on chips., B. Taiwan's military defense system., C. The physical durability of TSMC's fabs., D. A specialized technology that protects TSMC's intellectual property.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What company is described as "the world's most important company that you've probably never heard of" by Time magazine? Options: A. Nvidia, B. TSMC, C. Intel, D. Samsung Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary reason why a China-Taiwan conflict would be devastating for the global AI ecosystem? Options: A. The human toll would be too high, B. The global economy would suffer greatly, C. TSMC's chip fabrication facilities would be rendered inoperative, D. The conflict would disrupt global supply chains Correct Option: C
Question 3: What type of chip company designs but does not manufacture its own chips? Options: A. Foundry, B. Fabless chip maker, C. Semiconductor company, D. Integrated circuit manufacturer Correct Option: B
Question 4: Which of the following companies is capable of reliably producing the world's most advanced AI chips? Options: A. TSMC, Samsung, and Intel, B. Only TSMC, C. Only Samsung, D. Only Intel Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the main reason why TSMC has become a dominant force in the chip industry? Options: A. Its strategic location in Taiwan, B. Its ability to produce high-quality chips at a low cost, C. The powerful economies of scale in chip fabrication, D. Its strong partnerships with other companies Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the TSMC Grand Alliance, and how does it contribute to TSMC's success? Options: A. The TSMC Grand Alliance is a partnership between TSMC and the Taiwanese government, which provides TSMC with funding and resources., B. The TSMC Grand Alliance is a network of companies that work together to develop new chip technologies., C. The TSMC Grand Alliance is a group of companies that have developed their products in accordance with TSMC's road map, leading to powerful lock-in., D. Question 7: What is the "silicon shield" theory, and how does it relate to Taiwan's role in the global semiconductor industry? Options: A. The silicon shield theory states that Taiwan's central role in the global semiconductor industry protects it from invasion by China., B. The silicon shield theory states that Taiwan's semiconductor industry is vulnerable to disruption by China., C. The silicon shield theory states that the global semiconductor industry is dependent on Taiwan, but this dependence does not provide any protection against invasion., D. The silicon shield theory states that Taiwan's semiconductor industry is not important to the global economy. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What would happen to the global AI ecosystem if TSMC's chip fabrication facilities were rendered inoperative due to a China-Taiwan conflict? Options: A. The global AI ecosystem would be severely disrupted, but it would recover quickly., B. The global AI ecosystem would be mildly disrupted, but it would recover eventually., C. The global AI ecosystem would be devastated, and progress in AI would be profoundly disrupted., D. The global AI ecosystem would not be affected at all. Correct Option: C
Question 9: Which company is best positioned to step up and produce cutting-edge AI chips if TSMC's facilities are rendered inoperative? Options: A. Samsung, B. Intel, C. Nvidia, D. Google Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main challenge facing Intel as it tries to regain its chipmaking supremacy? Options: A. Intel's struggle to transition to new node technologies, B. Intel's lack of funding and resources, C. Intel's inability to compete with TSMC's economies of scale, D. Intel's failure to develop new chip technologies Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to ask about the concept of the "silicon shield" and its relation to Taiwan's role in the global semiconductor industry. The options provided in Question 7 are also similar to those in the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option (A) describing the silicon shield theory as stating that Taiwan's central role in the global semiconductor industry protects it from invasion by China.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set.
